introduction: Qalqalah means 'shaking' or 'disturbance.' It is a slight bouncing or echoing sound produced when any of five specific letters appear with a sukoon. Without qalqalah, these letters would be cut off abruptly because they have the attributes of jahr (stoppage of breath flow) and shiddah (stoppage of sound flow).
mnemonic_en: Remember: قُطْبُ جَدٍّ (Qutbu Jadd — 'axis of a grandfather')

levels.description: Occurs when a Qalqalah letter has a sukoon in the MIDDLE of a word. The echo is subtle and quick.

examples.rule_applied: Qalqalah Sughra — Qaaf (ق) with sukoon in middle of word
Qalqalah Sughra — Jeem (ج) with sukoon in middle of word

levels.description: Occurs when a Qalqalah letter has a sukoon at the END of a word, but NOT at the end of an ayah. The echo is moderate.

examples.translation: He neither begets nor was He begotten
examples.rule_applied: Qalqalah Wusta — Daal (د) at end of word, mid-ayah

levels.description: Occurs when a Qalqalah letter is the LAST letter of an ayah (or when you stop on a word ending with a Qalqalah letter). The echo is the strongest and most pronounced.

examples.translation: Say: I seek refuge in the Lord of daybreak
examples.rule_applied: Qalqalah Kubra — Qaaf (ق) at end of ayah

examples.transliteration: tabbat yadaa abee lahabiw wa tabb
examples.translation: May the hands of Abu Lahab perish, and may he perish
examples.rule_applied: Qalqalah Kubra — Baa (ب) at end of ayah (with shaddah, making it extra strong)

common_mistakes: Adding a vowel sound to the echo — Qalqalah should be a pure bounce, not 'ba' or 'bu' or 'bi'
Making the echo too strong in Sughra — it should be subtle
Making the echo too weak in Kubra — it should be clearly pronounced
Applying Qalqalah to letters that are NOT in the five (قطبجد)
